How does the central bank change the money supply for banks ?

1) When we deposit money in the bank, the bank holds a portion (this portion is called the Reserve Requirement) of the deposit and loans the rest.
So the central bank controls this portion.
If it's high, the bank can loan more of our money to other people and make profits (high money supply).
If low, they make less profit (less money supply).
Note:
The central bank is the bank of banks (they load from it).

2) Change the interest rate (discount rate) the central bank charges for loans the banks take.
Decreasing it, increases the money supply.
Increasing it, decreases the money supply.

3) Open market operations:
This is when the federal reserve buys or sells short term government bonds.
A government bond is an IOU (I Owe You) issued by the government which says I’ll pay you back later.
If the central bank buys those bonds from banks, it increases their money supply.
If the central bank issues more bonds to banks, it decreases their money supply.

Maybe my potential profits are too small and don't cover the interest costs, so lowering the interest rates will make some opportunities available that weren't before, but as those deals are made I would cease to borrow more money, unless new profit oportunities were provided for my bussiness.



A high or low interest rate is always high or low relative to the rate of profit of the investiment being made. So that a low rate yesterday could be a high rate tomorrow.


What if the rate of profit falls to negative in the aggregate? There isn't low enough interest rates to make someone sustainably invest in an economy that is burning cash. It is disturbing that in Oct-2015, when this video was published, the Fed was unable to conduct monetary policy as described in the video. The Fed really can't use open market operations to increase or decrease the money supply ... because back in 2014, the Fed had just finished 6 years of Quantitative Easing (aka "QE") which created a LOT money by buying a LOT of bonds with "newly-printed money" ... During these 6 years the Fed created $3.6 Trillion (in addition to the $900 Billion that the Fed had created by 2007) by buying medium-term bonds, rather than "short-term" bonds as (blatently) mis-mentioned in the video. (This raised the "average maturity" of the Fed's bond portfolio from 2.5 years in 2008, to 5 or 6 years in 2014.)


This $4.5 Trillion of "Fed-created-money" gives the Banking Industry the potential to create $45 Trillion (i.e., making Bank loans under the 10% reserve requirement) ... which would create a LOT of inflation, because most people don't want bank loans unless they have plans to spend it, or invest it (which ould produce an increase in aggregate demand in the economy. So, there's an argument that the Fed screwed up by not allowing the economy to recover quickly, because wen interest rates are SO LOW, the banks approve few loans because the ever-present risk of default is a larger problem compared to the interest rate). During the 6 years up to 2014, Banks made so few loans that they barely kept pace with the repayment of old loans in the normal course of business, so there was not much demand created by "new" bank loans. (I'll skip the idea that bank loans for investment purposes create an increase in goods and services, which offset the increase in money from such loans, so not much impact on inflation).


So the banks had a lot of "excess reserves" (money in excess of the 10% required reserve, which can be loaned out). The Fed would have crashed the economy if they had significantly reduced the money supply (i.e., reducing excess reserves) because that would have meant selling a LOT of bonds, which would have crashed the price of bonds (which raises the interest rate) as Uncle Sam (i.e., the Federal Gov't) was trying to raise money by selling more bonds to cover the huge budget deficit of roughly $1 Trillion, each year, for the next several years. The Fed had to hold on to their bonds. The money supply couldn't be reduced. Low interest rates may have kept Banks from lending as much as they would have with higher rates.


So, surely (or "probably" or "hopefully") having foreseen much of this. the Fed relied on the IOER (and then the IOR) to keep the interest rates from falling lower.
IOER = Interest Rate on Excess Reserves ... and .... IOR = Interest Rate on Reserves


I believe the IOER was originally conceived to keep banks from going bankrupt since the Fed may have foreseen that (in the near future) Banks would have so little revenue (interest income) from so few loans. Later on, perhaps, the IOR was employed as a tool to encourage banks to keep excess reserves in accounts at the Fed, from which they are not loanable. Sure, its voluntary, the amounts at the Fed can be retrieved "at will" by the Banks .... but there's way more money than the Banks can lend out, and the interest rates are (which depend on maturity and security) is so low that the ever-present danger of a loan default makes lending untenable to customers who expect a lower interest rate.

Summary:
1. Fed is the central bank of US
2. Central banks
a. regulate and oversee the nation's commercial banks by making sure that banks have enough money in reserve to avoid bank runs.
b. Conduct Monetary Policy which is increasing or decreasing the money supply to speed up or slow down the overall economy.
3. Interest Rate - The price of borrowing money
4. Loans depend on interest rates.
5. When Interest Rates are low, borrowers will find it easier to pay back loans so they will borrow more and spend more. When Irates are high, borrowers borrow less and therefore spend less.
6. Less money- higher interest rates
7. More money- less interest rates
8. Expansionary Monetary Policy- If the central bank wants to speed the economy, it increases the money supply which leads to decreased Irates and hence more borrowing and spending.
9. Contractionary Monetary Policy- To slow down the economy , decrease the money supply.
10. Recessionary Gap- Output low and unemployment is high.
11. Contractionary monetary policy drives down inflation but increase unemployment.
12. Two things keep the banking system healthy - Confidence (customers can get there money back) & Liquidity
13. Liquid Assets- an asset that can be converted into cash quickly and with minimal impact to the price received.
14. How does central bank change the money supply occur (3 Ways):
a. Changing the reserve requirement- decrease RR increase money supply and vice versa
b. Change the interest rate (discount rate) to the banks that borrow from Central bank. Decrease Discount rate will allow the other banks to borrow and hence increase the money supply
c. Open Market Operations- When the Fed buys or sells short term govt. bonds.
15. Govt. Bond or treasury bill is an IOU which says "I'll pay you later". If fed buys previously issued bonds from the local bank, it increases the money supply.
16. Fed usually use Open Market Operations to increase or decrease the money supply.
17. Quantitative Easing- When Central Banks buys long term assets from banks (like buying home loans).
18. Banks have to keep around 10% of their reserves.
19. Two ways in which we can speed up or slow down the economy:
a. Fiscal Policy- Changing government spending or taxes- for severe downturn.
b. Monetary Policy- Changing the money supply- for garden variety downturn

Some notes if anyone needs em!

-Federal Reserve is USA’s central bank, Europe has it’s own ECB, and other countries have their own versions, which have 2 main roles:
Regulate and oversee nation’s commercial banks by insuring they have enough money in their reserve to avoid bank runs
To conduct monetary policy which is increase or decrease the money supply to speed up or slow down the overall economy
-Interest rates = the price of borrowing money on top of the “principle” to cover inflation and ensure profit
-Low interest rates cause people to borrow more and spend more & vice versa
-FED doesn’t have the authority to change interest rates in US, so they change the money supply (increasing money supply increases the amount of loans commercial banks can give out)
-Decreased money supply = less money = higher interest rates on loans
-Central Bank can run an Expansionary Monetary policy by increasing the money supply
-The FED takes blame for the great depression as they let several large banks fail which caused a massive panic, and then ⅓ of all banks collapsed
-The economy is strong when there is confidence and liquidity (liquid assets = an asset that can quickly be converted into cash and with minimal impact to the price received → not stocks, bonds, or mortgages)
-Fractional reserve banking is when banks hold some of your deposit money but loan out the rest → reserve requirement is how much they are expected to keep
→ FED can change the reserve requirement (higher req = less money available)
-Discount rate = the rate which the FED charges banks (decreasing rate = more loans = more money supply)
-Open Market operations = when the FED buys or sells short term government bonds (govt. Bonds = treasury bills or IOUs)
→ buying bonds from banks increases its liquidity and increases the money supply
-In the USA the Federal Open Market Committee determines how many bonds to buy and sell
-In 2008 the FED tried Quantitative easing = central banks buy up longer term assets from banks → they bought short term and long term (like mortgage backed securities) using fake money → which causes inflation
-Excess Reserves = how much a bank can lend out

When you get a mortgage, the bank does not lend out huge sums of physical cash. Instead the bank would prefer you buy your house using your newly credited account. By doing so, the bank can settle the transaction with its account at the federal reserve. When banks settle transactions on behalf of their customers who make their payments, the net position of the banks are calculated and a net transfer of central banks reserves are made. For banks with a deficit, they can borrow from other banks or use the central banks standing facilities. For banks with a surplus of reserves, they can lend out the reserves or use the standing facilities for depositing excess reserves. In aggregate this means a redistribution of central bank reserves. Open market operations can also have a similar redistributing effect.

The money supply consists mainly of:
Central bank reserves = liabilities of the central bank and an asset for banks with an account at the Central Bank. Only banks with an account at the Central Bank can settle transactions in the manner I described above. Consequently central bank reserves circulate in a closed system. An increase in reserves does not necessarily mean an increase in the money supply. A genuine increase in the money supply would have to increase broad money, namely what the public holds, not some numbers in a closed off environment.

Bank deposits = bank liabilities, an IOU issued by banks which is basically a promise to repay the holder. In fact we shouldn't call it deposits because that implies you simply drop off cash at your bank. It ignores the fact that you can settle transactions with these deposits. Deposit is a euphemism. It's actually credit and its the banks who issue credit. By credit I mean a means of payment which is also a liability for the creditor. Banking is not about keeping some money and lending the rest, it's about substituting a commonly held means of payment by your own means of payment.

Cash = bank notes and coins, you all know what this one is. Technically they're also a liability of the central bank.

If you could only start off by defining the three main types of money in the money supply and elaborate on the payment system, you wouldn't get all this confusion and misunderstanding.

A further reading would be:
What is money - and easy introductory article on the ECB's website. Here some key terms are inside and outside money. Note there is no multiplier because banking does not work that way.
The infamous 2014 q1 quarterly bulletin bank of England money creation in the modern economy.
Om pengemengden - Marie Norum Lerbak (Norges Bank, bank of Norway. Sorry it's in Norwegian but the two above should be a decent introduction to banking in general)

Main outtakes of this lesson
1) The Federal Reserve is the central bank of US. Europe has the European Central Bank.
a. Most Central Banks have two jobs:
- they regulate and oversee the nation's commercial banks by making sure that banks have enough money in reserve to avoid bank runs.
- they conduct monetary policy which is increasing or decreasing the money supply to speed up or slow down the overall economy.
2) Interest rate - the price of borrowing money.
a. When interest rates are low, borrowers will find it easier to pay back loans so they will borrow more and spend more. When interest rates are high, borrowers borrow less and spend less.
b. Expansionary monetary policy - when central bank wants to speed up the economy, it will increase the money supply, which will decrease interest rates and lead to more borrowing and spending.
c. Contractionary monetary policy - when central bank wants to slow down the economy, they decrease the money supply. Less money available will increase interest rates and decrease borrowing and spending.
3) Liquid assets - an asset that can be converted into cash quickly and with minimal impact to the price received.
4) Open market operations - this is when the federal reserve buys or sells short term government bonds.
5) Quantitative easing (Q.E.) - when central banks buy longer term assets from banks.
6) Monetary policy - changing money supply to speed up or slow down economy.

It is important to remember that the Federal Reserve System is owned by the commercial banks; the Fed is not a government agency. Under the law that created the Federal Reserve System, the Fed became the only entity permitted to self-create credit. When the Fed issues new Federal Reserve Notes and then loans these notes to the U.S. Treasury, what is exchanged are IOUs for IOUs.

Now, let's examine the term "fractional reserves." When paper currency was redeemable in gold and/or silver coinage, but the bank issuing paper currency did not hold sufficient coinage to redeem 100% of the notes in circulation, this was when we had a fractional reserve system. Today, there is not requirement that anything tangible back the Federal Reserve Notes issued. There are no REAL money reserves backing this paper currency. Federal Reserve Notes are essentially promises to pay nothing in particular.

At best the federal reserve had a tertiary affect on the economy during the great depression. Certainly there were policies from the fed that helped create a stock bubble but bubbles come and go, the great depression was much more than that.

Our government already had disastrous banking regulations in place which significantly weakened the banks ability to survive downturns which was a larger impact than fed policy and directly resulted in many bank failures which did not happen in Canada since they did not have our banking regulations and their economy recovered without the tragic consequences we had in the U.S.

Government policies like increasing taxes and debt and restricting foreign trade probably had the largest effect since it was not until the Smoot-Hawley Tariff act was passed that unemployment really skyrocketed. Before that unemployment had peaked at around 9% from the market crash and was heading back down but then suddenly shot up to 25% soon after this particular anti trade act was passed.

Not ten years previously there was another very significant stock market crash but we don't hear about the great depression of 1921 because (nor any other time period after a large stock crash), while the fed was in place at the time, the government did not react to that crash with dozens of horribly backward policies.

A central banker like the Ben Bernank will obviously see the central bank as central to all of the economic issues at the time but this is a myopic view which ignores dozens and dozens of government actions that also made things worse and it ignores the rest of the world which generally weathered this period much more easily because they did not enact the policies we did.

Another thing regarding the affects of high interest rates mentioned in this video. Yes it may reduce investment but this increases the quality of investment. Meaning they will hold out and only lend to the best possible candidates and only those with the most confidence will want to get a high interest rate loan. Obviously this results in a much much lower default rate on bank loans which is very good for the economy. You can see the results of very low interest rates in the crash of 2008 when a few years previously rates had gone down to an unheard of 1% resulting in very risky and careless loans which obviously had a high chance of default as well as encouraging more people to seek loans when their financial stability was less than ideal.

Will you guys be doing a video about full reserve banking? From what I understand (which isn't all that much tbh, which is why I'd like a video to make sure I'm not misunderstanding anything here) fractional reserve banking means that the main creation of new money is in banks instead of at the fed, as the money not in reserve is given out and so belongs to multiple people at once, meaning, in essence, new money is created, however, it is based on debt. If full reserve banking were to be used then all new money creation could be held at the level of the fed through quantitative easing. The same amount of new money can enter the system, however, due to the money being created from a single central point it can be easily regulated, reducing speculation - all banks feeding large amounts of the newly created money directly into areas that look like they're doing well, creating bubbles, which eventually pop, causing financial crises. Full reserve banking would take some time to get to, as you couldn't starve the economy of money all in one go while banks get to the 100% reserve point, but in the long run it could reduce the chances of financial crises, and the fed could still direct the newly created money towards entrepreneurs and parties whose goal is beneficial to society, as opposed to just the places that will make the most money in the short run.
